Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[NuGet.org Bug]: A11y_NuGet Service_.Json_Version History_Screenreader : Narrator is not announcing column name as column header for "Version and Downloads"." (#8922) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Impact

It's more difficult to complete my work

### Describe the bug

Source: https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1438720

### Repro Steps

1. Hit the URL: https://www.nuget.org/ 
1.  Tab navigate to "Sign in" control and hit enter.
1.  Tab navigate to "Sign in with Microsoft" control and hit enter.
1.  Search for a key term (say ‚Äújson‚Äù) from search box.
1.  Click on "Newtonsoft.json" control and hit enter.
1.  Tab navigate to "Version History" control and hit enter.
1.  Turn on Narrator
1. Check Narrator is announcing column name as column header for "Version and Downloads".

Narrator is not announcing column name as column header for "Version and Downloads" column.

Note:
No issue observed in NVDA 
This issue is also reproducing in Statistics page also.



### Expected Behavior

Narrator should be announce column name as column header for "Version and Downloads" column.

### Screenshots

_No response_

### Additional Context and logs

_No response_

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Develop a package type checklist" (#7708) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
We should write-up a spec that calls out all **known** package type and their characteristics. 

Example **SymbolsPackage** and **DotnetTool** are 1 per package types. They cannot be combined with other package types. 

Related: 
https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/7337

#2476

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[Feature]: Show updates/issues in VS Solution Explorer for packages" (#11547) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

Other/NA

### The Elevator Pitch

When working within VS, the packages I use may have updates or may have issues (security issues, deprecations, etc) that I may want to be aware of.  Right now the only way to see that is launching the Package Management UI, but it isn't a normal thing I would do if nothing is alerting me to do that.

I propose that the Packages (and thus roll-up to the dependency node) node in VS should have different states for the packages listed...some examples:

- ‚ö†Ô∏è Warning: you should check this out and the hover tooltip would tell you something "Packages have information"
- ‚¨ÜÔ∏è or ‚ÑπÔ∏è Information/Upgrade: your packages have updates available
- ‚õî Error: for security check or deprecation message (tooltip would show)

Example:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4821/152074883-43644453-f288-4bb6-9396-9a01752946a3.png)


### Additional Context and Details

Part of this exists in VSMac already today.

Events.RelatedBody:
Follow up to https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/pull/2424

The tokenizers as written there are rather lacking.  They can be made linear and create less garbage.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Remote locals clear all button" (#10182) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "PMUI Consolidate Tab in VS.Oe" (#9552) at NuGet/Home
Closed issue "VS OE:  propagate exceptions consistently from service to client" (#10088) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Client code that was moved behind a VS OE service now has the potential of throwing a `StreamJsonRpc.RemoteInvocationException` where it threw some other exception type before.  In client code we sometimes have [specialized error reporting based on exception type](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/ba87e7e45851add0e46a217c14fa2c95973244a9/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.PackageManagement.UI/UserInterfaceService/NuGetUI.cs#L358-L405), so we should rethink this when VS OE services are involved.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "PM UI:  verify IVsPackageManagerProvider implementation still works in VS OE environment" (#10095) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
This is an exploratory task to determine what issues, if any, exist with NuGet's [alternative package manager provider support](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/1444) in a VS OE environment.  `IVsPackageManagerProvider` implementations may not just work in a VS OE environment, as some assumptions may now be invalid.

The only existing `IVsPackageManagerProvider` implementation I'm aware of is for web projects, but it's unclear if it applies to .NET Core (web) projects.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "VS OE:  near-duplicate Error List entries" (#10140) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
In VS OE scenarios only, near-duplicate Error List entries may display with only file paths differing.  This is not a regression from https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/commit/1f51ec51421a255c7fb83f362ee23839c0a5f631.

In general (VS OE and non-VS OE) and for a single [`ITableDataSink`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.visualstudio.shell.tablemanager.itabledatasink?view=visualstudiosdk-2019)), when the Error List already contains entries when new entries are added, the Error List overwrites an existing entry with a newer entry if their [`ITableEntry.Identity`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/microsoft.visualstudio.shell.tablemanager.itableentry.identity?view=visualstudiosdk-2019#remarks) values are equal.  Because [NuGet uses the message text for `ITableEntry.Identity`](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/1f51ec51421a255c7fb83f362ee23839c0a5f631/src/NuGet.Clients/NuGet.VisualStudio.Common/ErrorListTableEntry.cs#L21) and because these two entries have the same message, the first NU1101 entry is overwritten with the second NU1101 entry, and the entries are effectively deduplicated.

With the provided repro steps in a standalone (non-VS OE) environment, this deduplication occurs because both entries come from the same `ITableDataSink`.  However, in a VS OE environment, this deduplication does not occur because one entry is written by the service to the Error List and some background LiveShare magic propagates the entry to the Error List but with a it's own client-side `ITableEntrySink`.  The other entry is written by the client to the Error List with the NuGet `ITableEntrySink`. 
 Thus, the "duplicate" entries are not deduplicated.

Repro steps:

1.  Open a .NET Core project in a VS OE environment.
2.  In PM UI attempt to install a package that has a missing dependency.

Expected result:  

Actual result:


Severity | Code | Description | Project | File | Line | Suppression State
-- | -- | -- | -- | -- | -- | --
Error | ¬† | Package restore failed. Rolling back package   changes for 'NetCore'.
Error | NU1101 | Unable to find package IsMissingDependency. No   packages exist with this id in source(s): Test Packages | NetCore | C:\Users\dtivel\AppData\Local\Temp\4166FF91F1B149FE766E214BA1521E2B4224\2\~~\E$\Trash\VerifyFix\NetCore\NetCore.csproj | 1 | ¬†
Error | NU1101 | Unable   to find package IsMissingDependency. No packages exist with this id in   source(s): Test Packages | NetCore | E:\Trash\VerifyFix\NetCore\NetCore.csproj | 1 | ¬†

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "VS OE:  handle service unavailability changes and exceptions more centrally with better reporting" (#10168) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody: Perhaps have a wrapper for each service and handle possible issues (like `ObjectDisposedException`) more gracefully.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Create guidelines on changing brokered services" (#10248) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Update the [NuGet SDK docs](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGet.Client/blob/dev/docs/nuget-sdk.md), or create new docs so:

1. People (both in the NuGet Client team and other contributors) creating pull requests have a guide for how they can "correctly" modify either of our 2 Contracts assemblies
2. NuGet Client team members reviewing pull requests know what they should look for and can provide meaningful feedback

I know VS's brokered service APIs and recommendations are moving fast, but the NuGet Client team has already had people outside the team contribute changes that needed changes to our RPC contracts, and those of us not working on the VS.OE implementation need guidance on how we can review these changes effectively.

In particular, I'd like guidance on when it's acceptable to modify an existing service version, and when it's necessary to create a new service version. When we create a new service version, how do we implement graceful fallback or functionality degradation. If we're creating a brand new service, what should we do regarding new clients connecting to old servers that don't implement the service. Guidance on when to use long lived proxies, and when to use short lived proxies. Guidance on events/callbacks.
